newsitem.title: UK: London gold carves small gains, propped up by $340.
newsitem.headline: London gold carves small gains, propped up by $340.

text.p: London precious metal prices were expected to wobble on Thursday, but gold's support at $340.00 an ounce became stronger, paving the way for slight gains, traders said.
Gold moved higher after early buying interest emerged from London-based dealing houses between the $340 and $341 levels. Spot bullion fixed at $341.15, just above Wednesday's $341.00.
Dealers might have been tempted to protect call options accumulated around the $340.00 strike before Monday's OTC expiry, traders said.
"Probably we're looking up first, rather than down," said a London dealer adding that a small hike towards $342.00 could be expected today.
But activity was generally dampened by holidays, with the Jewish Passover all this week, while a week-long Moslem holiday has just finished.
Platinum and palladium moved sideways with no fresh news on delayed Russian platinum group metals (PGM) shipments.
But forward markets bubbled with good borrowing interest for short dates. That squeezed the lease rates, especially for one month.
"A lot of it is because nobody has got the liquidity so people are trading forwards rather than trading on the spots," said the London dealer.
One-month platinum lease jumped to 12.5 percent from around 10 while palladium was available at a steep 14 percent, dealers said.
The prospect of continued delays in PGM shipments from Russia, the world's biggest producer, is buoying the market, but the bubble is expected to burst once talks with Japan resume.
Moscow has yet to set the date to begin talks.

Gold is seen hovering above $340, at least until the options expiry, but upside progress will be limited by stiff resistance at $342.50. A test of last week's lows of $337.50 is also not ruled out in the coming days.
"People are trying to search for a bottom but we are going to manage to hold above the $340 support," said Magid Khoury, chief precious metals dealer at the Swiss-based Socofinance.
Silver moved in a thin range above $4.70, at $4.71/$4.73.
"People are still short. That's why we are not going lower than $4.70-$4.68," said Khoury of Socofinance, adding that failure in New York to pierce $4.68 proved strong support there.
